Spring 2022

Texas Gov. Greg Abbott begins sending recently arrived families to different sanctuary cities, including Washington, D.C., and New York City. Since August 2022, Texas has bused over 37,100 migrants to New York City.

Aug. 19, 2022

Mayor Eric Adams announces “Project Open Arms,” an interagency plan involving the New York City Department of Education, the Department of Social Services, and the Mayor’s Office of Immigrant Affairs, to assist families seeking asylum and ensure a public school education for their children.

Sept. 8, 2022

Over 1,400 recently arrived children begin their first day of classes at public schools across the city. P.S. 145 begins to see a steady enrollment of approximately five recently arrived children per day, according to the school’s community coordinator Juan Abreu.

Sept. 22, 2022

Adams announces the opening of the Humanitarian Emergency Response and Relief Centers to aid the increasing number of people seeking asylum in New York City.

Oct. 16, 2023

Adams announces that under a new policy, migrant families staying in city shelters will receive a 60-day notice to “find alternative housing.” Single adults would begin to receive 30-day notices, according to the policy.

Nov. 15, 2023

For the first time in eight years, enrollment at New York City public schools increases due to the influx of recently arrived children entering the school system.

Jan. 9, 2024

As the policy begins taking effect, recently arrived families who live in shelters that are not overseen by the New York City Department of Homeless Services are evicted and forced to reapply for a shelter placement under the new 60-day policy. However, families living in shelters under the department’s purview are spared the eviction notices for the time.

Aug. 20, 2024

Less than a month before the first day of school is set to begin, the city receives approval from state officials to start evicting the nearly 30,000 recently arrived children and parents staying in DHS shelters.

Oct. 2024

Thousands of migrant families who received notices in August are evicted from their shelters, disrupting children’s education and possibly uprooting them from their school community—for many, the main point of stability since their arrival in the city.

Source: Spectator reporting

Graphic by Jenny Ye
